summary:
I am a professional IT oriented person having specialties supports the day-to-day operations of a company’s computer systems and networks. 

My responsibilities include:

Monitoring and Maintaining Computer Networks: Keep an eye on network performance, troubleshoot issues, and ensure smooth functioning.

Troubleshooting System Failures: When something goes wrong, I can diagnose and fix problems, whether it’s a hardware glitch or a software issue.

Preparing Systems and Software Documentation: Create and maintain documentation related to system configurations, processes, and procedures.

currentPositions.description:
•	Conﬁgure & Management of Manage Engine Endpoint Central Cloud Solution
•	Conﬁguring & Managing of System Security using Manage Engine Solution
•	Monitoring Systems Health on daily basis and applying updated patches
•	Implement System Security to Lock endpoint devices that are managed through Active Directory using Manage Engine Solution.
•	Configure and Implement Mobile Device Management (MDM) in Manage Engine Solution
•	Implement System Security to Wipe the system Data if a Malicious Activity occur to endpoint device within organization using MDM Solution
•	Working on Azure Troubleshoot Developers Issues in continuous environment
•	Managing Oﬃce Network Infrastructure
•	Working on NGFW for Network Security (Fortinet)
•	Configure and Implement OpenVPN connectivity for remote user’s to work within organization’s Network using
Fortinet Firewall
•	Managing Internal Servers (DC, ADC, DB)
•	Working on Microsoft 365
•	Working on Microsoft Azure Services
currentPositions.title: Assistant Network Administrator

message.text:
Bugs in computers refer to errors, flaws, or faults in software or hardware that cause unexpected results, errors, or system crashes. Here are some common types of bugs:

1. Syntax errors: Mistakes in code writing.
2. Logic errors: Flaws in programming logic.
3. Runtime errors: Errors that occur during program execution.
4. Memory leaks: Unreleased memory causing performance issues.
5. Buffer overflow: Exceeding memory buffer capacity.
6. Null pointer exceptions: Accessing null or nonexistent memory.
7. Divide by zero errors: Attempting to divide by zero.
8. Infinite loops: Loops that run indefinitely.
9. Race conditions: Conflicts between concurrent processes.
10. Security vulnerabilities: Weaknesses that can be exploited by attackers.

Bugs can be caused by various factors, including human error, inadequate testing, and complexity. They can be identified and fixed through debugging, testing, and quality assurance processes.
